Award.AwardTitle: Scholars Award: Map Wars: The History and Sociology of Mapping Practices in Israel and the Palestinian Territories

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Introduction
This project explores the interlinkages between science, politics and state-making. The focus is on how the geographical sciences become entangled with politics, territorial claim making, and nation-state building in Israel and the Palestinian Territories since 1948 until today. Qualitative research methods such as in-depth interviewing, ethnography, and archival and library research will be used.

Intellectual Merits
This project investigates: how geography, cartography and mapping practices have become entwined with the building of nation-states; how social, institutional, and political contexts shape map-making; how various actors, institutions, and governments use maps to shape territorial visions; and how maps relate to material structures (such as the West Bank Barrier). The project also aims to develop a systematic and comprehensive methodology to analyze how social and political concerns become embedded in the visual rhetoric of maps.

Potential Broader Impacts
New mapping technologies and software greatly enable user-defined mapping practices. As a result, various social groups increasingly disseminate alternative mappings. In such an environment it is especially pertinent to focus scholarly attention on developing conceptual tools for understanding the rhetoric of mapping practices. The Israeli-Palestinian dispute over mapping provides a rich context for theorizing about alternative mapping practices so as to emphasize the importance of constructing integrative maps that recover diverse geopolitical visions. A careful analyses of how and why different adversarial groups map the same territory differently may serve as a resource for reconciliation; it will contribute to a better understanding of the historical and political genealogy of such diverging practices and provide insight into the social-ethnic histories of diverse populations in Israel and the Palestinian Territories, and in other suitably similar contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the beginning of the 20th century, the sciences have experienced a unique intermarriage with politics and have become a fundamental building block of the building of nation-states. Israel/Palestine reveals interlinkages between science, politics and nation-building more tangibly than places where the dust of history has long settled; it hereby provides a particularly rich laboratory to study the cartographic sciences and the making of maps as territorial boundaries continue to be controversial. In such areas of territorial conflict, nationally-based discourses about land, history and ethnicity inevitable turn maps into politics by other means. Both in Israel and the Palestinian Territories, governmental and non-governmental organizations, interest groups, and political protagonists produce a range of recurrent genres of maps for the purpose of delineating territories, parceling property, claiming land, as well as for helping to forge a territorial imagination and build the 'imagined community' of a nation. Such maps have different levels of legitimacy, reveal varied representational strategies, and serve various functions that make up the kaleidoscope of mapping practices present in Israel/Palestine. 

The rise of neoliberalism in the 1980s in tandem with new mapping technologies and online cartographic software increasingly transformed map-making from an expert's endeavor to a 'people's cartography'.  Consequently, various Israeli and Palestinian social and political interest groups are ever more designing maps to put forth varied geopolitical visions and demarcate disputed boundaries. Such 'map wars' are over the naming of different sites, the drawing of borders, as well as the delineation of spaces, that can either 'Judaize' or 'Arabize' territories, thus claiming them as belonging to a particular 'imagined community'.

The social history of map-making in Israel/Palestine reveals that both the making of the Israeli state as well as the attempt to establish a State of Palestine since the 1990s reaffirm the importance of geo-informatics in the service of state building for establishing land claims and improving governance. While maps continue to serve as crucial tools in building nation-states, they also have, however, become tools of resistance as activists design maps that continue to hunt the visionaries of dominant geopolitics.

In an era in which everyone with an internet connection and some mapping software can potentially partake in forging geopolitical visions, it is especially pertinent to focus scholarly attention on developing conceptual tools for understanding how maps serve as rhetorical tools that can put forth particular, socially constructed and politically charged visions of a territory. Such 'map wars' reveal the importance of integrating ethics into cartography. Critical cartographers have both experimented with re-signifying maps with the spaces and names of indigenous people erased from maps, and revealed the social and political concerns that inform maps made by different socio-ethnic groups. At the same time, new technologies such as Geographic Information Systems (GIS) can now serve as tools for territorial analysis and mediation in territorial disagreements, once disputants agree on the relevant data to be incorporated in the software.

Tracing the diverse socio-historical experiences of Israelis and Palestinians as they manifest themselves in maps also has policy relevance. Social scientists and historians concerned with advancing peace in the Middle East have increasingly drawn upon their disciplines in order to promote a more in-depth understanding of the roots of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Social psychologists published school textbooks that represent the Palestinian and Israeli versions of history side by side in order for children to learn to understand the multiple and frequently contradictory nature of the historical and political experience of both peoples, and archeologists have traced archeological sites that reveal Israel/Palestine's rich and diverse historical past that entails compiling an online searchable map of archeological sites that could serve as a basis for more effective dialogues about contentious cultural heritage sites in a final status agreement. This project aims to increase scholarly and public appreciation for understanding science, and in particular cartographic practices, in their cultural, social and political context. Moreover, by contextualizing cartographic practices in terms of their socio-ethnic politics, this project also provides a framework for enhancing more effective dialogue concerning strategies for reconciliation and peace-building in Israel/Palestine and beyond.
